"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Congress finds that the United States is facing a crisis in writing skills, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills result in high private-sector costs for training. Writing is crucial for employment and promotion, and is a key feature in educational standards. The only national program addressing this issue dates back to 1973. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, is the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools. Evaluations show significant improvements in student writing and classroom practices. It serves as a model for enhancing teaching in various subjects like math, science, history, and more. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, is the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools. Each year, over 135,000 teachers benefit from its programs in nearly 200 sites across the United States and its territories. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, is the only national program addressing the writing problem in schools. Subpart 2 of part C of title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to focus on the National Writing Project. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, aims to expand its network of sites across the United States, ensure high-quality programs through evaluation and support, disseminate effective teaching practices, and coordinate activities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The National Writing Project, established in 1973, aims to expand its network of sites across the United States and coordinate activities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization focused on improving student writing and learning. The grant aims to enhance writing instruction in classrooms by partnering with higher education institutions or other educational providers. The National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization, will partner with contractors to establish teacher training programs for effective writing instruction. Funds from the Secretary will cover the Federal share of program costs, and the grantee must meet additional conditions set by the Secretary. The National Writing Project will establish teacher training programs for effective writing instruction, with funds from the Secretary covering program costs. The programs will train teachers from kindergarten to college, and select teachers to join a National Writing Project teacher network to conduct writing workshops for other teachers. The National Writing Project will establish teacher training programs for effective writing instruction, with the Federal share covering 50 percent of program costs. Teachers from all disciplines are encouraged to participate in these programs. The Secretary may waive the Federal share requirement on a case-by-case basis. The National Writing Project will establish teacher training programs with a Federal share of costs up to $150,000 per contractor. A National Advisory Board will be established to oversee the programs. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board consisting of national educational and writing leaders to advise on student writing and teaching issues. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board to advise on student writing and teaching issues, review activities and programs, and support continued development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs to specify funds expended for administrative costs. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board to evaluate teacher training programs and allocate funds for administrative costs. The Secretary will reserve up to $150,000 annually for this purpose. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board consisting of leaders in research in writing to review and recommend applications for funding. Authorization of Appropriations: $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding for the following 5 years.
